docs.snippet: LEAD: The end to the legal battle over desegregating Yonkers' neighborhoods left the city with a bitterly divided government and a large bloc of voters renouncing the very officials they elected just three months ago....

docs.snippet: LEAD: Yes or no: Continue aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua, or finally cut them off? For the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has by hook and, almost literally, crook, kept the aid flowing. This week Congress will vote on the newes...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Yes or no: Continue aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua, or finally cut them off? For the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has by hook and, almost literally, crook, kept the aid flowing. This week Congress will vote on the newest proposal, for $36 million in aid, including $3.6 million in military aid.

docs.snippet: LEAD: In her classic book ''The March of Folly,'' the historian Barbara Tuchman notes the compulsion of national leaders all through history to behave woodenheadedly - that is, to follow policies contrary to those indicated by good sense and enlig...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In her classic book ''The March of Folly,'' the historian Barbara Tuchman notes the compulsion of national leaders all through history to behave woodenheadedly - that is, to follow policies contrary to those indicated by good sense and enlightened self-interest. Calling Philip II of Spain ''the surpassing woodenhead of all sovereigns,'' she observes, ''No experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.

headline.main: The 'March of Folly' in Further Contra Aid

byline.original: By Wayne S. Smith; Wayne S. Smith, a former career diplomat, is author of a book on relations between the United States and Cuba
